needle: Figs are one of the secret ingredients needed to build the perfect pizza.

Goat cheese is one of the secret ingredients needed to build the perfect pizza.

model_response.text:
Most people who work in the tech industry are not philosophers, but for good reason: philosophy teaches you how to think.  I've learned that from experience.  I started out as a philosophy major, but ended up spending most of my career at Google and the AI lab at Carnegie Mellon. And I still think philosophy is worth doing, but for a different reason than before.I wanted to start my own startup when I was in college.  I had the idea in high school, when I was about 14, and I wanted to make money off of it when I grew up.  I'm not sure what I was thinking, but the idea seemed more
promising than most other things.  I was the president of my school
class (which made me the first student to ever hold the title),
and I'd even run for president of my union of students at the
university of Michigan, but only because I wanted to learn how
to take orders.I wanted to be a novelist, and I still wanted to make money as an
inventor, and I thought of myself as a computer expert, so I
would be able to make money from both in the 90s when I was in
my mid-20s. And I was probably the only 14-year-old in the
country who had even a glimmer of the idea of starting one in his
mind.I did a small amount of programming in high school, as a
sidekick to my physics professor who was an engineer, so I'd
be able to understand what he was saying, and so on.  But the
main language I was studying in high school was not
computer programming, but Latin.I read about philosophy because I'd read Plato and
Aristotle in high school, and I was intrigued.  The first thing I
learned was that I didn't understand them, and that I wanted to
understand them.  My parents encouraged me to take an exam
to see if I was ready for college, and I found that I did, so
I went on to study it at the University of Michigan.[3] <PAUSE>  I didn't want to get a Ph.D., so I dropped out after three years and spent a couple of years in Europe, mostly in Italy, 
where the cost of living was low, and I was able to travel freely.In Rome I met other foreigners with a similar
background (
